title: Garnet-type Li<sub>7</sub>La<sub>3</sub>Zr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>12</sub> Electrolyte Prepared by a Solution-Based Technique for Lithium ion battery
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>High quality garnet-type Li<jats:sub>7</jats:sub>La<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>Zr<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> solid electrolyte was synthesized using a solution-based technique. The electrolyte pellets were sintered at 900 <jats:sup>o</jats:sup>C, resulting in tetragonal phase, which then transformed to cubic phase after annealing at 1230 <jats:sup>o</jats:sup>C. The ionic conductivity of both phases was studied and revealed to be 3.67x10<jats:sup>-7</jats:sup> S/cm and 1.67×10<jats:sup>-4</jats:sup> S/cm, respectively. A proto-type cell comprising of Li<jats:sub>7</jats:sub>La<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>Zr<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> electrolyte, LiCoO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> cathode and lithium metal anode was assembled. The cell made with the cubic phase electrolyte exhibited superior performance than the one made with the tetragonal phase electrolyte. The former cell possessed a very promising gravimetric discharge capacity of 3.4 mAh/g, which is the highest value obtained among similar setups.</jats:p>

title: Properties of surface film on lithium anode with LiNO3 as lithium salt in electrolyte solution for lithium–sulfur batteries
Electrochemical Performance of Solid‐State Lithium–Air Batteries Using Carbon Nanotube Catalyst in the Air Electrode
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Solid‐state lithium–air cells using lithium anode, a polymer electrolyte, Li<jats:sub>1+<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>+<jats:italic>y</jats:italic></jats:sub>Al<jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic></jats:sub>(Ti, Ge)<jats:sub>2−<jats:italic>x</jats:italic></jats:sub>Si<jats:sub><jats:italic>y</jats:italic></jats:sub>P<jats:sub>3−<jats:italic>y</jats:italic></jats:sub>O<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> inorganic solid electrolyte, and an air electrode composed of carbon nanotubes and an inorganic solid electrolyte are constructed and their electrochemical properties investigated. The cells show a reversible capacity of about 400 mA h g<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> during the first few cycles. The rate performance and impedance measurements are also examined. The large cell resistance, which mainly comes from the interfacial resistance between Li and the polymer electrolyte, limits the rate performance. The results indicate that such all‐solid‐state lithium–air batteries without polymer electrolytes have good potential for development.</jats:p>
